title: Getinge Servo-i Ventilator Expiratory Cassette Errors
description: Guide for troubleshooting expiratory cassette errors on a Servo-i ventilator, focusing on external causes before repair.

steps.title: Ensure the ventilator is powered off before handling the cassette
steps.instructions: Safety first: avoid disconnecting tubing or cassettes while the device is active on a patient.

steps.title: Verify expiratory cassette installation
steps.instructions: Remove and reinstall the expiratory cassette. Listen for the “click” indicating it is fully seated. Misalignment can cause error codes.

steps.title: Inspect cassette and sensors for debris or damage
steps.instructions: Check for moisture, secretions, or obstructions in the expiratory cassette. Ensure the sensor ports are clean and unobstructed.

steps.title: Check expiratory tubing connections
steps.instructions: Confirm all patient circuit tubing is securely connected. Ensure there are no kinks, pinches, or leaks that could trigger cassette errors.

steps.title: Run a ventilator self-test
steps.instructions: After verifying installation and connections, power on the ventilator and initiate a system self-test. Observe whether the expiratory cassette error clears. If the error persists, note the exact error code for escalation.

steps.title: Verify software and calibration status
steps.instructions: Ensure the ventilator’s software is up to date. Confirm calibration logs do not indicate failed expiratory cassette calibration.

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator displays expiratory cassette error code during setup.
CCR.Cause: Cassette was not fully seated; tubing connections were loose.
CCR.Resolution: Reinstalled expiratory cassette, secured tubing connections, ran self-test—device passed and returned to service.

helpfulDetails: Tubing checked for leaks or kinks
Final device status: Ready for patient use or Out of Service

title: Getinge Servo-i Ventilator - Flow Sensor or Volume Measurement Errors
description: Guide for troubleshooting flow sensor errors and tidal volume discrepancies on Getinge Servo-i ventilators, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Power and Startup Sequence
steps.instructions: Confirm the ventilator is properly powered and the battery is charged. Check that the ventilator completes its self-test without unexpected alarms. Why: Incomplete self-tests or unstable power can trigger false flow errors.

steps.title: Inspect Patient Circuit Connections
steps.instructions: Ensure inspiratory and expiratory limbs are correctly connected. Confirm that filters, humidifiers, and heat moisture exchangers (HMEs) are properly seated. Why: Leaks or misaligned tubing can cause erroneous volume readings.

steps.title: Check Flow Sensor (Pneumotach) and Adapter
steps.instructions: Remove and visually inspect the flow sensor for condensation, debris, or damage. Ensure the sensor is installed in the correct orientation according to the device labeling. Why: Obstructions, moisture, or incorrect installation can trigger measurement errors.

steps.title: Inspect Circuit for Leaks
steps.instructions: Perform a leak test if the ventilator supports it. Check all connections, including endotracheal tube cuff seal, Y-piece, and filters. Why: Leaks affect tidal volume delivery and flow measurement accuracy.

steps.title: Check Humidification and Condensation
steps.instructions: Drain excess water from heated circuits or HMEs. Confirm that the flow sensor is dry. Why: Condensation in the sensor or tubing alters flow and volume readings.

steps.title: Swap with Known Good Consumables
steps.instructions: Replace the flow sensor or adapter with a verified functioning unit. Replace disposable patient circuit if necessary. Why: Confirms whether the error is due to consumable components rather than the ventilator hardware.

steps.title: Verify Settings and Calibration
steps.instructions: Confirm ventilator mode, tidal volume, and circuit type are correctly configured. Re-run calibration or zeroing procedures as per normal operating procedure. Why: Incorrect configuration can cause alarms for “flow error” or “volume discrepancy.”

CCR.Complaint: Ventilator displays “flow sensor error” and delivered tidal volume inconsistent.
CCR.Cause: External inspection revealed condensation in flow sensor and minor leak at Y-piece connection.
CCR.Resolution: Drained condensation, secured connections, replaced disposable sensor and patient circuit, recalibrated ventilator. Verified proper tidal volume delivery.

title: Getinge Servo-i Ventilator - Fails Pre-Use Check / 'Leak Detected'
description: Guide for troubleshooting a Getinge Servo-i ventilator that fails pre-use check with a 'Leak Detected' message, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Ensure Device Is Powered and Stable
steps.instructions: Verify the ventilator is plugged into a functional outlet. Check that the battery (if present) is charged and the unit is powered on. Why: Low or unstable power can cause false leak detection.

steps.title: Inspect the Breathing Circuit
steps.instructions: Ensure all tubing (inspiratory and expiratory limbs) is correctly connected. Confirm that tubing is free of kinks, cracks, or holes. Remove and reconnect tubing to ensure secure connections. Why: Even a small disconnection or crack can trigger a leak alarm.

steps.title: Check the Patient Interface
steps.instructions: Inspect the endotracheal tube, mask, or other patient connector. Ensure the device is properly attached with no loose connections. Why: Leaks often occur at the interface rather than inside the ventilator.

steps.title: Inspect the Exhalation Valve / Humidifier
steps.instructions: Remove or check the exhalation valve for proper seating. If a heated humidifier is attached, confirm all connections are tight and tubing is intact. Why: A misaligned valve or humidifier connection can mimic a leak.

steps.title: Verify the Circuit Type Selected in Software
steps.instructions: Ensure the ventilator software settings match the connected circuit (adult, pediatric, neonatal). Why: Mismatched settings can cause pre-use check failures.

steps.title: Perform a Manual Leak Test
steps.instructions: Disconnect from the patient. Close the circuit as recommended in the user interface. Run the ventilator’s 'circuit check' or leak test again. Why: Confirms whether the leak is in the patient circuit or the ventilator.

steps.title: Replace Consumable Components if Needed
steps.instructions: Swap out disposable circuits or valves with known-good units. Why: Consumables are common sources of leaks and are easily replaced without opening the ventilator.

CCR.Complaint: Pre-use check fails with ‘Leak Detected’ message.
CCR.Cause: Observed loose circuit connection at inspiratory limb. No cracks in tubing, valves seated correctly, no patient connected. Leak persisted after reconnecting.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced disposable breathing circuit with a verified functional circuit. Pre-use check passed successfully. Ventilator returned to service.

helpfulDetails: Final device status: Functional, returned to service
